clinical_study.brief_title: An International Survey on Hypoglycaemia Among Insulin-treated Patients With Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: An International Survey on Hypoglycaemia Among Insulin-treated Patients With Diabetes

brief_summary.textblock: This study is conducted in Europe. The aim of the study is to gather information about hypoglycaemia (low blood glucose) among patients with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study is both retrospective and prospective.

primary_outcome.time_frame: In the 4 weeks prior to and following the baseline visit (Week 0)

secondary_outcome.measure: Difference in the reported incidence rates of any hypoglycaemia
secondary_outcome.time_frame: In the 4 weeks prior to (Part 1) versus following (Part 2) the baseline visit

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of hypoglycaemic events requiring hospital admission
secondary_outcome.time_frame: In the 6 months prior to and 4 weeks following the baseline visit

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of all severe hypoglycaemic events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: In the 6 months prior to and 4 weeks following the baseline visit

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of probable symptomatic hypoglycaemic events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: In the 4 weeks prior to and following the baseline visit

intervention.description: Patients will be asked to complete a two-part patient self-assessment questionnaire (SAQ) comprising a retrospective cross-sectional evaluation (Part 1), and a prospective observational evaluation (Part 2).

study_pop.textblock: Insulin-treated patients with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients should be ambulatory, literate, have used insulin for at least 12 months, and be over 18 years of age to be able to participate in the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin for more than 12 months
- Patients giving informed consent to participate in the survey
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-ambulatory patients
- Illiterate patients and patients otherwise unable to complete a written survey
